    copulaStan: Fitting Bivariate Gaussian and Clayton Copulas
  • Changelog

    Fit Bivariate Copula Model with Optional Marginal Parameter Estimation

    fit_bivariate_copula.Rd

    The `fit_bivariate_copula` function fits a bivariate copula model to data with optional marginal parameter estimation. It supports Gaussian and Clayton copulas, and allows for specifying normal or lognormal marginal distributions for each variable. This function utilizes Stan for Bayesian inference, offering flexible control over the sampling process.

    Usage

    fit_bivariate_copula(
  U,
  copula,
  marginals = NULL,
  iter = 2000,
  chains = 4,
  warmup = 1000,
  thin = 1,
  seed = NULL,
  control = list(adapt_delta = 0.8, max_treedepth = 10),
  cores = 1
)

    Arguments

    U

    Data matrix of observed marginals, with two variables.

    copula

    The type of copula to fit. Options are "gaussian" and "clayton".

    marginals

    A list specifying the marginal distributions for each variable. Options are "normal" and "lognormal".

    iter

    Number of iterations for each chain. Default is 2000.

    chains

    Number of chains. Default is 4.

    warmup

    Number of warmup iterations per chain. Default is 1000.

    thin

    Thinning rate. Default is 1.

    seed

    Random seed. Default is NULL.

    control

    A list of parameters to control the sampler's behavior. Default is list(adapt_delta = 0.95, max_treedepth = 10).

    cores

    Number of cores to use for parallel processing. Default is 1.

    Value

    A list containing:

    fit

    The fitted Stan model object.

    Examples

    if (FALSE) {
library(copulaStan)
library(copula)

seed <- 2024
set.seed(seed)
true_rho <- 0.5
n <- 2000

margins <- c("norm", "lnorm")
params <- list(list(mean = 0.8, sd = 2), list(meanlog = 0, sdlog = 0.8))
cop <- normalCopula(param = true_rho, dim = 2)
mvdc_copula <- mvdc(cop, margins = margins, paramMargins = params)
data <- rMvdc(n, mvdc_copula)

fit <- fit_bivariate_copula(data, copula = "gaussian", marginals = c("normal", "lognormal"),
                            iter = 4000, chains = 4, warmup = 2000,
                            seed = seed, cores = 4)
}
